newsitem.title: GERMANY: Krupp takeover seen sparking merger wave.
newsitem.headline: Krupp takeover seen sparking merger wave.

text.p: The European steel industry could be headed for a wave of consolidation if Fried. Krupp AG Hoesch-Krupp is successful in its takeover of German rival Thyssen AG, analysts said on Tuesday.

The takeover, which Thyssen planned to fight, would produce a giant that rivals Europe's top heavyweight, France's state-owned Usinor Sacilor, and increase pressure on others to merge, streamline and strengthen, analysts said.
"Steel companies have remained nationalistic, more so than chemical companies, and there could be more cross-border tie-ups," said Merrill Lynch steel analyst Alan Coats in London.

"The heart of the European steel industry is in Germany, with the most consumption, and the most suppliers," Coats said. "If Germany restructures, and the trend becomes more European, European steel makers will be more able to move into global thinking."
Analysts said the European steel industry has too many small players and needs to consolidate to reduce overcapcity problems and improve profit.

Together, Krupp-Thyssen would account for 75 percent of German steel production, with particular strength in flat steel, and could realise tremendous savings in capital expenses and other costs, they said.

"The two companies have combined about 195,000 employees, and some would have to go," said Terance Sinclair at Salomon borthers in London. "If they got rid of five percent they could double their margins. They could easily get rid of 10,000 to 20,000, but the final number is anybody's guess."
A new, competitive German giant would raise the stakes on others to merge, possibly a takeover of Spain's state-owned Cia. Siderurgica Integral by Usinor Sacilor, analysts said.
Other possibile merger candidates would include Arbed SA of Luxembourg and Belgium's Cockerill-Sambre SA.
